awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Investigating the Commercialization of Peer Review Tools and Writing Analytics
awd_abstract_narration:
Current measures of coaching and assessing student writing, while time consuming and well intentioned, fail to provide students with the feedback they need to improve as writers and peer reviewers. Improving feedback and assessment of students' writing is critical to U.S. efforts to compete globally. Currently, U.S. rankings for literacy have been declining over the past decade: in 2012, the Programme for International Student Assessment concluded that the U.S. literacy rate fell from 10th to 20th in the latest study on global rankings. In 2013, the College Board reported 57% of SAT takers did not qualify as college ready. The ACT found 31% of high school graduates failed to meet ACT College Readiness Benchmarks, and the most recent NAEP Writing Report determined 73% of 12th graders received scores of Below Basic or Basic as opposed to Proficient or Advanced in 2011. Few educators or students dispute the importance of quality feedback on students? writing. However, over the past 100 years, researchers have repeatedly found that teachers' grades lack validity and reliability; that teachers' comments on papers often lack helpful, critical commentary; and that students do not know how to critique other students' writing even though they are frequently assigned peer-reviews. While teachers? shared use of rubrics has led to improved inter-rater agreement scores?especially in testing situations where teachers can practice scoring to reach stronger levels of consensus?comparisons of teachers' scores across sections of the same course in authentic learning contexts has found great variance in teachers' scores and comments.

This research seeks to help expedite document markup, peer-review, team-project, eportfolio, and writing-assessment processes; empower instructors and students to provide more helpful, timely feedback; better prepare students for peer reviews and team projects; and enable high schools, colleges, and universities to more accurately assess learning, improve retention, and prepare accreditation reports. Ultimately, this research aspires to conceptualize digital tools that will enable the U.S. to complete on global measures of cognitive, interpersonal and intrapersonal competencies. During the I-Corps program, the team will interview academic stakeholders (writing program administrators, faculty, and university administrators who are concerned with retention and business stakeholders (technical writing firms, competitors, and NLP researchers)?to evaluate mockups for writing analytics, student-retention alerts, data visualizations, and intelligent tutoring systems. For example, the team will ask writing program administrators if they would be likely to adopt and use tools that provide inter-rater agreement reports on instructors? scores in relation to students' peer-review scores or lexical analysis of the instructors? and students? written commentaries. Additionally, the team will hold focus groups with instructors and students to ascertain the helpfulness of NLP-based reports that vet peer reviews. Ultimately, this research will explore the efficacy of second-generation digital tools?i.e., tools that provide writing analytics that give information back to users based on their use of a tool, such as lexical analysis of comments, reports of inter-rater agreement among reviewers, reports that analyze the length and quality of feedback, or badges that incentivize quality reviews. By the end of the I-Corps program, the team will prioritize a development plan and a business plan that will allow for commercialization of the technology, My Reviewers http://myreviewers.com.

por.por_cntn:
MyReviewers is a suite of software tools developed at the University South Florida (USF). These tools are designed to improve document markup, peer review, and writing program assessment. At USF, MyReviewers is presently used by approximately 18,000 users, including approximately 10,000 chemistry students. The goal of I-Corps: Investigating the Commercialization of Peer Review Tools and Writing Analytics was to learn about entrepreneurship from NSF and assess whether the tool set is commercially viable at schools beyond USF.

The PI, Mentor, and Entrepreneurial Lead conducted over 100 customer discovery interviews using I-Corps methods. By conducting these interviews, the investigators hoped to gather insights for improving document-review, peer-review, and writing program assessment tools. These interviews enabled the team to

  • continue development of the tools in a prioritized manner 
  • develop a professional network to inform future development and collaborations
  • create a blog to inform stakeholders regarding related research and developments: http://myreviewers.com/blog/
  • write a customer-oriented NSF SBIR, which was subsequently funded by NSF. This new proposal conducts research on the technical feasibility of machine-based, real-time formative feedback. 

The PI and Entrepreneurial Lead were interviewed on TV by ABC and Fox. Several articles about the effort were published on the USF portal.  The project received the Campus Technology Award from Campus Technology, a weekly magazine serving IT managers in postsecondary education. As a result of a related effort, NSF Prime, the PI also presented and published broadly on the project (see http://myreviewers.com/publications).

At the NSF I-Corps training in Atlanta, the team was encouraged to focus on a particular market rather than explore a range of markets, such as the Global English or K-12. Subsequently, the team investigated  composition, professional and technical writing, and scientific writing markets at the postsecondary level. As a result of this investigation, the team learned the biggest impediment to commercialization was stakeholder’s resistance to using new tools.  Even though stakeholders commonly expressed dissatisfaction with their institutions’ LMS tools—whether it was Canvas, Blackboard, or Desire2Learn, or Moodle—they expressed reluctance to adopt another toolset. That said, all stakeholders—administrators, instructors, and students—described traditional methods for responding to student writing—as painful, exhausting, and counterproductive. Additionally, administrators expressed concern about the lack of training of their graduate students and adjuncts, and they would like resources to help train instructors and students with document review. They worry novice instructors under their supervision provide poor feedback and that existing methods of grading are unfair to students. One well known writing program administrator described efforts to develop writing analytics as the devil’s work. A number of administrators in the humanities reported concerns that machined-based feedback will further exasperate the poor labor conditions of faculty/adjuncts in the humanities. Administrators reported tools that would help them assess their writing program would help them gain additional resources. 

Faculty across disciplines expressed dissatisfaction with traditional methods for responding to writing. They remarked they worry about the poor quality of students’ scientific writing. Some faculty reported avoiding writing assignments because they don’t want to grade student work. STEM faculty reported losing time responding to grammar and mechanics rather than scientific reasoning, and they expressed a desire for machine-based formative feedback. In contrast, faculty in the humanities expressed animosity toward machine-based formative work.

Regarding the postsecondary market, the team concluded product-market fit could only be achieved for administrators who were concerned about the mentorship of their faculty or needed to facilitate writing program assessment. To have any success in the postsecondary market, the team also concluded it needed to achieve integration with existing LMS tools. To achieve successful commercialization—to get beyond the LMS obstacle—the team concluded it needs to develop “special sauces”—tools that significantly improve feedback, mentorship, and writing program assessment.

Given the size of the potential market, the intensity of the pain associated with instructor or peer feedback, the team remains committed to pursuing the development of commercial solutions. That said, the team recognizes it needs to facilitate writing program assessment or formative feedback to be competitive in the postsecondary market.

Patents

No patents have been issued.

Licensing Agreements

MyReviewers LLC has secured a licensing agreement with USF: LIC14003. This agreement provides MyReviewers LLC with the exclusive rights to sublicense the MyReviewers software suite.

Company Formation

MyReviewers LLC has been established. Currently, MyReviewers LLC leases coworker space at MyReviewers LLC, USF Connect Tampa Bay Technology Incubator, 3802 Spectrum Boulevard, Box 8, Slot 5, Tampa, FL 33612

Royalties Realized

No patents have been issued.

SBIR Proposal Submission

Two SBIRs have been submitted, one to NSF and one to IES.  NSF funded NSF SBIR, Phase 1: https://www.nsf.gov/awardsearch/showAward?AWD_ID=1721749.

Third Party Funding

No third-party funding was issued.

New Curriculum Development

customer discovery interviews led to software development as well as the creation of new rubrics and Community Comments—that is, multimedia explications on the genre of lab reports.
